title-group.article-title: Examination of Hashin’s failure criteria for the second world-wide failure exercise

author-notes.corresp: G Kress, Structure Technologies, ETH Zürich, Leonhardstr. 27, CH-8092 Zürich, Switzerland Email: gkress@ethz.ch

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Evaluation of Theories for Predicting Failure in Polymer Composite Laminates Under 3-D States of Stress: Part A of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II)

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The second world-wide failure exercise is an international activity, organised by Kaddour and Hinton, aiming at a better understanding of the limitations of existing failure criteria to predict failure under triaxial stressing. The present work is a response to an invitation to take part and employ Hashin's failure criteria to the 12 test cases defined by the organizers of the second world-wide failure exercise. Methods, based on nonlinear analysis, used to perform the required simulations are explained and the predictions are presented. Observed problems are discussed.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: An international activity, called the world-wide failure exercise (WWFE), contained a detailed assessment of 19 theoretical approaches for predicting the deformation and failure response of polymer composite when subject to biaxial states of stress. Investigated aspects included initial failure prediction, multiple sources of nonlinearity including progressive damage, and final failure strength prediction. Results are summarized and assessed in Reference [1] where the publications created through the activity are referenced. Triaxial stressing of composite materials occurs in many situations, including the self-equilibrating of stresses found at the free edges of multidirectional polymer composite laminates and has received considerable research attention since 1970,2 see Reference [3] for an overview and the same authors with a recent contribution.4 According to linear elastic theory, the distribution of the interlaminar stresses exhibits a singularity at the free edge so that fracture mechanical methods5 must be employed to predict failure. Away from the free edges of thin laminated plates or shells, the stressing in each layer remains plane if the Kirchhoff-Love6,7 assumptions apply. Such situations occur in typical aerospace lightweight applications where the existing point-stress criteria, based on stress values, for failure prediction of composites are applied most often. Point-stress failure criteria are applicable to triaxial stressing caused by other mechanisms than free-edge effects and where the stresses are more evenly distributed. Such mechanisms are observed in laminates used for designs of a more compact geometry which appear with increasing frequency, for instance load introduction into drive shafts,8 composite springs, or moderately thick curved laminated shells for which methods for the calculation of interlaminar normal stress are being developed.9 A new activity, WWFE-II, is an extension to the previous exercise and looks into the current trends and assesses the understanding of the failure behaviour of fiber-reinforced polymer composites under triaxial loads.10 Participants of the exercise are provided with a description of the 12 test cases and the associated composite laminates.11

The input data include the three-dimensional (3D) elastic constants, 3D ultimate strains and strengths, and some of the nonlinear stress–strain curves for five unidirectional laminae and their constituents. Five types of laminates are described together with the loading conditions.

sec.title: Present work
sec.p: The present work applies the specified stress states to the laminates to produce the failure envelopes as predicted by Hashin’s failure criteria12 which are recalled in Hashin’s failure criteria. They are failure functions whose values depend entirely on stresses. It is therefore that the stresses, specified to be applied on unidirectional laminates (test cases 1 through 7), enter the criteria directly and the provided material nonlinearity plays no role as it does not change the stresses to be inserted into the failure functions. Only the calculation of the strain–stress or stress–strain curves specified in test cases 3 and 4 requires including the material nonlinearity and we explain the scheme that we use for it in Nonlinear materials response simulation. The stresses specified to be applied to the multidirectional laminates, test cases 8 through 12, must be used to calculate the layer stresses because Hashin's criteria are meant for unidirectional composites and, therefore, must be evaluated on layer level. Triaxial local layer stresses occurring in the multidirectional laminates are calculated by using a homogenization model. It has been developed previously13–15 and a summary of it is here placed in Appendix A. It must not be confused with the well-known theory of laminated plates16 because the latter considers, with the Kirchhoff-Love assumption,6,7 plane stress states only. Instead, it finds averaged 3D laminate properties in terms of the layer properties and Laminate layer stresses explains how it connects specified triaxial laminate stressing with the local stress states in the individual layers. Of course, all multidirectional laminate test cases require nonlinear analysis. For specified stress ratios, the corresponding points on the failure envelopes are calculated by the extrapolation scheme explained in Failure envelope calculation and it provides critical load factors also in the presence of fixed, or invariant, stresses. Residual stresses contains a few remarks on residual stresses; however, we do not want to invent our own extended versions of the test cases and therefore perform the calculations without assuming residual stresses. A multidirectional laminate may suffer initial damage and take further load increase before its ability to transfer even higher loads reaches a limit. We have not undertaken progressive damage analysis17 in this work and the discussion in Post-failure analysis explains the reasons. We have not addressed the question of how to realize the stress states, specified for the test cases, in physical experiments.

sec.title: Hashin’s failure criteria
sec.p: From the failure criteria for unidirectional fiber composites, existing before 1980, the maximum-stress and maximum-strain criteria and the criteria provided by Tsai,18 Tsai and Wu,19 and Hoffman20 count among the most well-known. The maximum-stress criterion does not consider stress-interacting effects and thus tends to make nonconservative predictions. On the other hand, the other three mentioned criteria do not predict failure mode; an ability that is necessary for damage progression analysis. They also contain some physically unacceptable features that have been exposed in the literature.12,21 Hashin's failure criteria12 form a set of smooth branches of the failure surface or envelope, each of which models a distinct failure mode, and thus overcome the deficiencies of previous criteria. The work must also be credited for having inspired, or laid a basis for, further progress throughout later years. Hashin's thoughts on the failure-plane orientation being a function of the applied stress state have been elaborated by others to build more complex failure theories for predicting strength along with failure plane orientation.22 Hashin formulates his criteria in terms of the first four stress invariants with respect to rotation about the fiber direction 1 (1)I1=σ1I2=σ2+σ3I3=τ23 2-σ2σ3I4=τ12 2+τ13 2 and the material strength values. Therefore, and if the load is specified in terms of stresses, nonlinear material behaviour has an effect on the failure envelopes of multidirectional laminates only. The derivation of the four criteria, namely for tensile fiber failure (1), compressive fiber failure (2), tensile transverse failure (3), and compressive transverse failure (4), is explained in Reference [12] and we write them here directly in terms of the invariants: (2)I1≥0:f1=(I1σA +)2+I4τA 2=1I1≤0:f2=(I1σA -)2=1I2≥0:f3=(I2σT +)2+I3τT 2+I4τA 2=1I2≤0:f4=[(σT -2τT)2-1]I2σT - +(I22τT)2+I3τT 2+I4τA 2=1

Hashin’s12 notation of 1D failure stresses reflects the assumption that unidirectional fiber composites not only are transversely isotropic in terms of elasticity properties but also that ZT = YT = σT + , ZC = YC = σT-, and S13 = S12 = τA. The material information given in Table 111 specifies values for all of these strength values separately. However, only the specified data for the materials IM7/8551-7, where YT = 73 MPa and ZT = 63 MPa, and S2-glass/Epoxy2, where YT = 63 MPa and ZT = 50 MPa, contradict the transverse-isotropy assumption. The figure (Here: Figure 3) in Reference [12] illustrates that the failure envelope within the σ2-σ3 plane is not closed and the opening is within the region where both stresses are compressive. This has to do with the fact that in deriving the criterion for compressive matrix failure, f4, Hashin uses the argument
“ … that if the material is failed in transversely isotropic pressure, all others vanish, σ22 = σ33 = −σ, σ > 0, this pressure will be much larger than the compressive uniaxial failure stress. Thus σ ≫σT-.”

This circumstance causes the anticipated results that in test cases 2, 3, and 5 the failure envelopes in the compressive region of σ2 are closed only because it is specified that σ1 = σ3 = σ2 and eventually compressive fiber failure is predicted when σ1 = −XC. In test cases 6 and 7 the failure envelopes must remain open.

Note that Hashin’s criteria compare a stress state with a set of measured strength values without describing the mechanisms leading to failure, such as for instance kink-band formation under longitudinal compression.

sec.title: Nonlinear materials response simulation
sec.p: The instructions to contributors11 provide material data with initial moduli and also stress–strain curves for the unidirectional composites as well as the isotropic matrix materials in bulk form. Following the representation given by Reddy,23 we consider the nonlinear equation (3)C(ε)ε=σor mathvariant="bold">R(ε)=0 where ε is the solution to be determined, C(ε) is a known function of ε, σ are the externally applied stresses, and R is the residual-stress vector (4)R(ε)=C(ε)ε-σ

With the direct iteration method, also explained in Reference [23] and using secant rather than tangent stiffness matrices as illustrated in Figure 1, one starts with an initial guess for ε, say ε(0) = 0, and determines a first approximation to ε by solving the equation (5)ε(1)=(C(ε(0)))-1σ Figure 1.
Direct iteration method (after Reference [23]).
The algorithm continues with (6)ε(r)=(C(ε(r-1)))-1σ and terminates upon fulfillment of the convergence criterion (7)(ɛ(r)-ɛ(r-1))2(ɛ(r))2<ρ
For predicting failure by using Hashin's stress-based criteria, the test cases require non-linear calculation only if a multidirectional laminate is subject to specified averaged stresses.

The material nonlinearity can be tracked and modelled only on layer level, by calculating the stresses and strains in material principal coordinates. To obtain these from the specified laminate stress states, the averaged laminate stiffness matrix Clam is calculated by using the homogenization method explained in Appendix A.1. Inverting it gives the laminate compliance matrix (8)Slam=(Clam)-1
Multiplying the laminate compliance matrix with the laminate stress vector obtains the averaged laminate strains (9)ε=Slamσ

From the strain and the stress vectors, the quantities constant throughout the thickness are assembled into vector l0 and, for a particular layer k, the matrix multiplication (A.7) finds its individual quantities rk. The next step assembles the layer strains and stresses (A.4) and (A.5) so that the transformation into the layer's principal material directions can be performed. Then the elastic moduli are updated from the given stress–strain curves by (10)E⊥ (r)=σ⊥(ɛ⊥ (r))ɛ⊥ (r)υ⊥|| (r)=-ɛ||(ɛ⊥ (r))ɛ⊥ (r)G⊥|| (r)=τ||⊥(γ||⊥ (r))λ||⊥ (r)

Here, we have chosen the subscript symbols ||⊥ to indicate that the stress components along the directions 2 and 3 contribute to the actual stressing of the material, (11)σ⊥=σ2σ3+τ23 2=I3τ||⊥=τ12 2+τ13 2=I4

The stress–strain curves are given in terms of data points and, for writing the nonlinear program, it appears convenient to replace these by smooth representations. We have obtained best-fit polynomials in the form (12)σ(ɛ)≈a0+a1ɛ+…+a6ɛ6

Then, the current respective secant moduli are used to update the laminate stiffness matrix Clam (ε). These steps are included in the iterations of the direct method until the convergence criterion (7) applies. Clearly, the method takes the multiple nonlinearities into account; in other words, the model allows for the nonlinearities in shear and compression. The transverse and through-the-thickness components of transverse compression result in the value of σ⊥ in equation (11).

sec.title: Laminate layer stresses
sec.p: Test cases 8 through 12 consider the strength of multidirectional laminates under stresses defined in reference xyz coordinates. The respective fiber directions 1 of the individual layers are measured in degrees where the 0-degree direction coincides with x. The direction transverse to the fibers and within the x-y plane is denoted with 2, and the interlaminar axes 3 and z coincide, see Figure 2.

Predicting laminate strength, against initial failure, by use of Hashin's failure criteria, is the same as performing a first-ply failure analysis and for it the layer stresses in principal material directions must be known. We calculate the layer stresses with our homogenization model, explained in Appendix A, by the following steps.
Calculate homogenized laminate compliance Slam as explained in Appendix A.
Apply a stress combination σlam, selected from the test case envelope, to obtain the laminate averaged strain vector εlam=Slamσlam.
Collect the components from σlam and from εlam which remain constant throughout the laminate thickness and assemble them into the vector I0 as defined with (A.6).
Calculate with (A.7) the vector rk (A.6) of magnitudes, which may vary from layer to layer, for the kth layer.
Assemble layer stress vector of kth layer with σx k=r1 k, σy k=r2 k, σz k=l3 0, τyz k=l4 0, τxz k=l5 0 and τxy k=l6 0.
Transform the layer stresses into the principal material directions by a rotation about the z axis, which is for instance explained in Reference [16].

sec.title: Failure envelope calculation
sec.p:
Intersecting the failure surfaces corresponding with the individual test cases with planes of constant stress gives the failure envelopes presented in Application to the test cases. As Figure 3 illustrates, we identify points on the closed failure envelopes by using an angular parameter θ, specifying a ratio between the two explicitly drawn stress components and the load factor λ, (13)σordinate=λsinθ,σabscissa=λcosθ which is the ratio between the applied stress state and the critical stressing causing failure. It must therefore be linearly connected with the stress components whose critical values are to be predicted by stress criteria. In addition, several of the test cases superimpose the envelope stresses σE with some fixed stress state σF. We therefore arrange that (14)σ=λσE+σF Figure 2.
Coordinate and stress conventions on laminate and layer levels.
Inserting equation (14) into the conditions equation (2) generally gives a quadratic equation for λ of the form (15)λ2Q+λL+P=1.
If the fixed loads P are not high enough to cause failure by themselves (P ≥ 1), the load factors for the envelope stresses are obtained by resolving equation (15): (16)λ=-L+L2+4Q(1-P)2Q

It is thinkable that the value of Q may be so small that dividing by it will cause numerical error. In such a case, and if L≠0, solution accuracy of λ is retained by defining the error function e, (17)e=λ2Q+λL+P-1 and using the Newton-Raphson method24,25 for finding the root of it by iterations: (18)λ(k+1)=λ(k)-ee',e'=dedλ=2λQ+L

When predicting the failure envelopes for test cases 8, 10, and 11, which consider multidirectional laminates, the magnitude of the laminate stress states must satisfy the applicable Hashin's failure criterion. Because of the material nonlinearity, the load factor λ cannot be exactly calculated by the linear extrapolation (equation (16)). However, the extrapolation is used for estimating the critical stress state until, upon convergence with respect to the material nonlinearity, the result of (equation (16)) becomes equal, or close enough, to unity.

sec.title: Residual stresses
sec.p: Residual stresses exist if the free-strain values in the two or more constituents of a composite material differ from each other. The stresses may be considered on two different size scales. The residual stresses distributions on the smaller scale, at the order of one fiber diameter, are caused by the mismatch between the free strains of the fibers and the matrix material. They should lead to observable dependence of the transverse uniaxial failure stresses of the unidirectional laminates. The strength data11 do not include information on their temperature dependence.

The residual stress distributions on the larger scale of a layer thickness are connected with the layer arrangement of multidirectional laminates. A linear material model facilitates estimation of the residual stresses by assuming an elevated stress-free reference temperature and use the difference between it and the temperature at which physical strength testing is performed. The residual stresses superimpose the stresses caused by mechanical loading and the simulation can improve failure load prediction. In view of large strains and nonlinear stress–strain curves, it remains unclear how to include the residual stresses correctly.

sec.title: Post-failure analysis
sec.p:
Individual layers of multidirectional laminates may often suffer matrix cracking without destroying the overall integrity, or load-carrying ability, of the laminate. Predicting laminate strength then requires a post-failure, or progressive damage, analysis. The accuracy of such calculations depends much on the effort invested in modelling the material degradation of the damaged layers. We do not intend to pursue post-failure analysis since
– Hashin's theory does not include degradation models
– Predicting of transverse-failure plane orientation would require theories that are not included in Hashin's equations. We will instead point out situations where initial failure should coincide with final failure or not.

sec.title: Computer code
sec.p: A program reads the laminate definition and layer properties and writes to a text file data points which are points on either the predicted failure envelopes or the predicted stress–strain (or strain–stress) curves. The data are read into EXCEL to produce the curves shown in the figures of this paper. A rough flow chart of the subroutine organizing the calculation of a failure envelope is shown in Figure 4. Verification and validation of the program has been part of the work presented herein.

For instance, local layer stresses in the layers of a multidirectional laminate subject to external in-plane stresses, if no bending occurs, must not depend on whether they are calculated by existing laminate analysis programs or the new code. We use for laminate analysis after the classical theory of laminated plates our own code CAP which has been in use for more than 20 years. The results of the code and CAP have been compared regarding the layer stresses and strength predicted with Hashin's criteria in plane-stress situations and no discrepancy has been detected. The simulation of material nonlinearity has not been validated with other programs.

sec.title: Application to the test cases
sec.p:
The cases 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, 10, and 11 specified in Table 1 are requested to produce failure envelopes. When simulating test case 4, first the isotropic pressure and then the shear loading must be applied until final failure takes place. Test case 9 requires that first an isotropic pressure of 100MPa be applied and the resulting strain values be recorded. Then the stress σy is to be increased beyond -100MPa until final failure takes place. Table 1.
Details of the test cases, Reference [11]
Case Laminate Material Description of required prediction
1 Resin MY750 σx versus σz (with σy = σz)
2 0° T300/PR319 τ12 versus σ2 (with σ1 = σ2 = σ3)
3 0° T300/PR319 γ12 versus σ2 (with σ1 = σ2 = σ3)
4 0° T300/PR319 Stress strain curves (τ12 − γ12), (σ1 = σ2 = σ3 = 600 MPa)
5 90° E-Glass/MY750 σ2 versus σ3 (with σ1 = σ3)
6 0° S-Glass/epoxy σ1 versus σ3 (with σ2 = σ3)
7 0° A-S carbon/epoxy σ1 versus σ3 (with σ2 = σ3)
8 ±35° E-Glass/MY750 σy versus σz (with σx = σz)
9 ±35° E-Glass/MY750 Stress–strain curves (σy − εx, σy − εy), σz = σx = −100 MPa
10 [0,90, ±45]s IM7/8551-7 τyz versus σz (with σy = σx = 0)
11 [0,90]s IM7/8551-7 τyz versus σz (with σy = σx = 0)
12 [0,90]s IM7/8551-7 Stress–strain curves σz − εz, σz − εx, σz − εy for σy = σx = 0

sec.title: Test case 1
sec.p: This case considers bulk resin MY750 Epoxy to predict the σx versus σz (with σy=σz) failure envelope. We do not consider any specific test specimen geometry and must therefore assume that the prescribed stresses remain spatially constant. Therefore, and even if yield and ultimate stress values were included in the material data, we could not distinguish between yield and ultimate strength predictions. We require that strength predictions should rely on Hashin's stress-based criteria and no other theory or knowledge should be used for improvement. In addition, both the loading and the failure criteria are given in terms of stresses and a homogeneous material is considered. Thus, the material nonlinearity cannot have an influence on the predictions. The material isotropy provides us with two approaches of applying Hashin's equations to this test case; one identifies the stress σ2, appearing in the definition of the stress invariants (equation (1)), with one of the stresses σy or σz and the other one identifies σ2 with σx. The first approach obtains the non-zero stress invariants (19)I1=σxI2=2σzI3=-σz 2I4=0 and the latter gives (20)I1=σzI2=σx+σzI3=-σxσzI4=0

It is interesting to note that only the latter case creates stress interactions, namely in the tensile and compressive matrix failure modes 3 and 4, respectively. The failure envelopes obtained by using sets (19) and (20) are plotted in Figure 5. Envelope branches corresponding to the failure modes are indicated with text. The first approach giving the invariants (equation (19)) produces the rectangular envelope whereas the shape of the envelope after (equation (20)) reflects the existing stress interactions. The more conservative strength predictions given by either of the two envelopes lie on the edge of the area marked with the hatched lines. Figure 3.
Illustration to failure envelope calculation with equations (13) and (16). Figure 4.
Calculation steps for producing a failure envelope.

In order to expose the influence of triaxial stressing as compared to biaxial stressing, the latter is shown in Figure 6. Figure 5.
Prediction of the triaxial failure envelope for epoxy materials used for Test case 1.

sec.title: Test case 2
sec.p: This case considers the unidirectional reinforced composite T300/PR319 to predict the τ12 versus σ2 (with σ1=σ2=σ3) failure envelope. The stress invariants used in Hashin's theory become (21)I1=σ2I2=2σ2I3=-σ2 2I4=τ12 2

Here, the unidirectional failure stresses have the values XT=1378MPa, XC=950MPa, YT=40MPa, YC=125MPa, S12=97MPa, and S23=45MPa. Comparison with a biaxial case σ3=0 exposes the influence of triaxial stressing and gives the invariants (22)I1=σ2I2=σ2I3=0I4=τ12 2

Figure 7 reveals the difference between the strength envelopes for triaxial and biaxial stressing, which is striking particularly in the compressive regime of σ2. Figure 6.
Prediction of biaxial failure stresses of an epoxy material.

Under triaxial stressing and with τ12=0, compressive fiber failure is predicted by f2 at σ1=σ3=σ2=-950MPa. At this point in stress space, the value of the failure function for compressive matrix failure is negative, namely f4=-14.12.

In the case of biaxial stressing, it can be verified that setting σ2=-YC=-125MPa satisfies the condition f4=1. The area enclosed by the envelope for biaxial stressing is marked with a crossed-line pattern. The tensile fiber-failure mode occurs only for the biaxial stress situation.

sec.title: Test case 3
sec.p:
This case considers the unidirectional reinforced composite T300/PR319 to predict the γ12 versus σ2 (with σ1=σ2=σ3) failure envelope. Hashin's criteria predict failure loads on the basis of stresses and therefore this case differs from case 2 only by plotting shear strain γ12 corresponding to the enveloping shear stress values τ12, rather than the shear stresses themselves. Consequently, the invariants are the same as in the previous test case 2 (equation (21)). The shear strain γ12 is obtained from the shear stress τ12 by using the measured stress–strain data points given in Table 9 in Reference [11]. The envelope based on the nonlinear material is plotted in Figure 8 with solid lines. For assessing the influence of the nonlinearity, we also produce a plot for an assumed linear material where the strain is calculated from the stress by using (23)γ12=τ12G12 and where the constant G12 is the initial modulus of the nonlinear material. The envelope for the assumed linear material is plotted in Figure 8 with dashed lines. Figure 7.
Theoretical failure envelope of a UD carbon/epoxy lamina under combined shear and hydrostatic pressure loading (Test case 2).

sec.title: Test case 4
sec.p:
This case considers the unidirectional reinforced composite T300 = PR319 to predict the τ12 versus γ12 (at σ1=σ2=σ3=σ=-600MPa) stress–strain curves. The stress invariants used in Hashin's theory become (24)I1=σI2=2σI3=-σ2I4=τ12 2 and because of the fixed isotropic pressure, σ=-600MPa, only the criteria for compressive fiber and transverse failure can here be applied. In view of the unidirectional failure stresses given in Test case 2 the fixed isotropic pressure cannot cause failure by itself: the compressive fiber failure function f2(σ)=0.3989 is not coupled with shear and the compressive transverse failure function value f4(σ,τ=0)=-8.9185 renders the critical shear stress value quite high: failure occurs at τ12=±305.49MPa. Figure 9 includes a shear stress–strain curve based on assuming a linear material whose engineering constants are given in Table 1.11 It reaches to the strength limits predicted if the fixed isotropic pressure exists. Without the isotropic pressure, the strength limits are much smaller, and the stress–strain curves corresponding to this are drawn with a thicker line. Whether isotropic pressure is included or not, the material nonlinearity has only an effect of the strain limit. Unfortunately, the nonlinear material data are provided only up to the unidirectional failure stress S12=97MPa. We have assumed that for shear stresses τ12>S12, the secant modulus remains constant which reflects in the shape of the non-linear curve in Figure 9. Figure 10 shows the curves within the stress limits that are reached if no isotropic pressure is applied. Figure 8.
Theoretical failure envelope of a UD carbon/epoxy lamina under combined shear and hydrostatic pressure loading (Test case 3) (dashed lines for a linear material behaviour). Figure 9.
Predicted shear stress–strain curve under a hydrostatic pressure −600 MPa for a UC carbon/epoxy material (Test case 4).

Finally, we summarize that Hashin's theory predicts a strong increase in limit shear stress on account of the fixed isotropic pressure and that the material nonlinearity increases only the predicted limit shear strain.

sec.title: Test case 5
sec.p: This case considers the unidirectional laminate E-Glass/MY750 epoxy to predict the σ2 versus σ3 (with σ1=σ3) failure envelope. The stress invariants used in Hashin's theory become (25)I1=σ3I2=σ2+σ3I3=-σ2σ3I4=0

Here, the unidirectional failure stresses have the values XT=1280MPa, XC=800MPa, YT=ZT=40MPa, YC=ZC=145MPa, and S23=50MPa. The functions for fiber failure prediction depend only on σ1=σ3; not modelling any stress interacting effects. If σ2 and σ3 have similar values within the compressive regime, the predicted strength limits are set by the failure function f2 for compressive fiber failure (because of σ1=σ3).

If one assumes linear material behavior and uses the data given in Table 111 to describe it, one obtains at the point in stress space, σ1=σ2=σ3=-800MPa, strains ɛ1=-0.78 %, and ɛ2=ɛ3=-2.48 %. The envelope is given in Figure 11. The nonlinear strains must be larger, but we cannot specify their values because the unidirectional compressive stress–strain curves are provided within the stress 0>σ2>-145MPa only. Figure 10.
Uniaxial shear stress–strain curve for a UC carbon/epoxy material used to solve Test case 4.

sec.title: Test case 6
sec.p: This case considers the unidirectional laminate S-Glass/epoxy2 to predict the σ1 versus σ3 (with σ2=σ3) failure envelope. The stress invariants used in Hashin's theory become (26)I1=σ1I2=2σ3I3=-σ3 2I4=0

Here, the unidirectional failure stresses have the values XT=1700MPa, XC=1150MPa, YT=63MPa, YC=180MPa, ZC=180MPa ZT=50MPa, and S23=40MPa. Note that transverse failure stresses in the in-plane and thickness directions differ from each other. The form of Hashin's criteria provides one with the choice of identifying σT + with either YT=63MPa or ZT=50MPa. Figure 12 gives the envelopes for each choice and the more conservative envelope resulting from σT +=50MPa bounds the hatched area. Both envelopes predict the same values for σ1 to cause tensile and compressive fiber failure, respectively. The value of σ3 for causing tensile matrix failure depends on the choice mentioned above. Figure 11.
Theoretical failure envelope (σ2 versus σ3 = σ1) of a UD E-glass/epoxy lamina (Test case 5).

The envelope does not enclose the region σ3<0 because of σ2=σ3 and the circumstance addressed at the end of Section 2.1. Drawing the plot up to the value of the unidirectional failure stress YC is an arbitrary choice.

sec.title: Test case 7
sec.p:
This case differs from test case 6 only by the considered material. Here, it is A-S carbon/epoxy with values XT=1990MPa, XC=1500MPa, YT=ZT=38MPa, YC=ZC=150MPa, and S23=50MPa. For this case, the same remark, made in the last paragraph of the preceding subsection, applies. Figure 13 gives the envelope. Figure 12.
Theoretical failure envelope (σ1 versus σ3 = σ2) of a UD carbon/epoxy lamina (Test case 6).

sec.title: Test case 8
sec.p:
This case considers the bidirectional laminate [±35]s whose layers consist of E-Glass/MY750 epoxy (see test case 5) for unidirectional failure stresses) to predict the σy versus σz (with σx=σz) failure envelope. The envelope based on assuming linear material properties is plotted with dashed lines and the nonlinear envelope is plotted with solid lines in Figure 14. The two envelopes are identical where tensile matrix failure is predicted, they remain similar in large parts where failure under compressive matrix failure is predicted, and they diverge from each other on where they predict compressive fiber failure. Figure 13.
Theoretical failure envelope (σ1 versus σ3 = σ2) of a UD S-glass/epoxy lamina (Test case 7).

We find it illustrative to expose the layer stresses in principal material directions for two points of applied laminate stresses. The one point is the stress σy=100MPa and it evokes the stresses in the two layers with the fiber orientations ±35∘ as listed in Table 2. Table 2.
Local layer stresses equilibrating σy = 100 MPa
σ1 σ2 σ3 τ23 τ13 τ12
35° 38.8 61.2 0.0 0.0 0.0 49.1
–35° 38.8 61.2 0.0 0.0 0.0 –49.1

Note that the stresses in the two layers differ from each other only by the sign of the in-plane shear stress τ12. Since the sign of the shear stress is without influence on the stress effort, the two layers share the same failure probability. The other point we consider in laminate stress space is σx=σz=100MPa and the corresponding layer stresses are listed in Table 3. Table 3.
Local layer stresses equilibrating σz = σx = 100 MPa
σ1 σ2 σ3 τ23 τ13 τ12
35° 79.1 20.9 100 0.0 0.0 −42.6
−35° 79.1 20.9 100 0.0 0.0 42.6

Since these invite the same comment as those listed in Table 2, and for the linear calculation the stressing in each layer must be a linear combination of the stresses given in each table, any first-ply failure analysis under the linearity assumption must predict that failure happens simultaneously in both the +35° and - 35° layers. Figure 15 provides further insight into the distribution of local stresses (top plot) and failure functions (bottom plot) in the +35° layer of the laminate. Figure 14.
Theoretical failure envelope (σy versus σz [with σx = σz]) of a ± 35° angle ply laminate made of E-glass/epoxy material (Test case 8).

All quantities are plotted along the linear failure envelope shown in Figure 14 and the abscissa is the arc length spanning a full circle. The local stresses are critical and equilibrate the laminate stress points on the linear failure envelope. The failure functions are marked by the patterns of the enclosed areas: horizontal and vertical lines indicate fiber and matrix failure, respectively, and thin and thick lines indicate tensile and compressive failure modes, respectively.

In addition, the critical failure mode of each branch is marked with text. The correspondence of both plots with each other is most clearly seen within the region labelled “compressive fiber” where the stress σ1 remains at the unidirectional failure stress σA -=XC=-800MPa and the failure function for compressive fiber failure is unity, or f2=1.

The stress vector given for the +35° layer in Table 3 appears pre-multiplied with different factors at the positions θ=0, θ=π, and θ=2π, where the first and third positions are identical points on the envelope. The other stress vector, given in Table 2, appears pre-multiplied with different factors at θ=π/2 and θ=3π/2. The linear and the nonlinear failure envelopes plotted in Figure 14 are rather close to each other except along the branch where compressive fiber failure is predicted. In contrast to the stresses, the linear and nonlinear strain envelopes agree with each other only along the branch of tensile matrix failure as can be seen in Figure 16 and for the other branches the material nonlinearity increases the laminate strains at failure. Clearly, the compressive-fiber failure branches of both the linear stress and the linear strain envelopes branches must lie on a straight line because failure is predicted if σ1=-800MPa and from the local layer stresses given in Tables 2 and 3 it follows that the line equation of the compressive fiber failure branch is, in terms of stresses, (27)σy=-10.388(800MPa+0.791σz) Figure 15.
Linear failure stresses and failure functions in Layer 1 (Case 8).

Obviously, the straight lines must become curved lines when material nonlinearity is considered, but it remains to be an irresolvable modelling problem that the predicted compressive failure stresses are much higher than the values up to which nonlinear stress–strain curves are provided. The stress and strain envelopes shown in Figures 15 and 17, respectively, refer to initial failure. We cannot predict the damage and its effect on the laminate behaviour without using other means than provided by Hashin's failure criteria. Figure 16.
Predicted failure strain (εy versus εz) envelopes for the linear and nonlinear material models (Case 8).

Although we do not analyze final failure, we can comment that the initial and final failure predictions must closely agree if not coincide along the compressive-fiber-failure branch and also along the parts of the envelope where the laminate is torn apart under a delamination failure mode.

sec.title: Test case 9
sec.p:
This case considers the laminate [±35]s made from E-glass/MY750 epoxy to predict the σy versus εx and σy versus εy (at σz=σx=-100MPa stress-strain curves. The laminate average elastic properties are the same as for test case 8. Isotropic pressure, σx=σy=σz=-100MPa, is equilibrated by the layer stresses listed in Table 4. Uniaxial stress, σ¯y=-100MPa, gives the negative values of the layer stresses listed in Table 2. Table 4.
Local layer stresses equilibrating isotropic pressure σx = σy = σz = –100 MPa
σ1 σ2 σ3 τ23 τ13 τ12
35° −117.9 −82.1 −100 0 0 6.5
−35° −117.9 −82.1 −100 0 0 −6.5

Superimposing these two load cases gives the layer stresses listed in Table 5 and it becomes obvious that first-ply failure will be compressive transverse failure because the condition σ2+σ3<0 will apply and the failure load will be determined by satisfying Hashin's fourth failure criterion f4=1. Table 5.
Superposition of the stresses listed in Tables 4 and 5
σ1 σ2 σ3 τ23 τ13 τ12
35° −156.7 −143.4 −100 0 0 −55.6
−35° −156.7 −143.4 −100 0 0 55.6

Table 6 records the strains after applying the isotropic pressure σy=σz=σx=-100MPa. The linear (dotted lines) and the nonlinear (solid lines) stress–strain curves for increasing isotropic pressure are plotted in Figure 17. Table 6.
Laminate strain response to isotropic pressure
Strain (%) Linear Nonlinear
εx −0.108 −0.106
εy −0.227 −0.230
εz −0.343 −0.356

The local layer stresses listed in Table 4 hold equilibrium to the maximum applied isotropic pressure and are well within the value range of the provided nonlinear transverse compressive stress–strain of the E-glass/MY750 lamina. The second part of test case 9 is to increase the magnitude of σ2 beyond σ2=-100MPa, whilst keeping σx=σz=-100MPa, gradually until final failure takes place, and to produce the σy versus εx and σy versus εy curves. The linear and nonlinear versions of them are plotted in Figure 18. The nonlinear analysis predicts the laminate failure load σy ult slightly lower (299 MPa) than the linear analysis (286 MPa). The nonlinear stress–strain curves include inflection points just before the final-failure load. The cause is simply that, at the failure load predicted by Hashin's criteria, the local lamina stresses σ2 exceed the range for which uniaxial nonlinear stress–strain data are available. Figure 17.
Predicted strain versus hydrostatic pressure (σy = σx = σz) for a ± 35° angle ply laminate made of E-glass/epoxy material (initial part of Test case 9).

Instead of extrapolating the curves we have assumed that the secant modulus at higher stresses remains at the value calculated by dividing the respective maximum values of the given stresses and strains. A damage progression analysis was not performed.

sec.title: Test case 10
sec.p:
This case considers the quasi-isotropic laminate [0,90,±45]s whose layers consist of IM7/8551-7 to predict the τyz versus σz (with σy=σx=0) failure envelope. Equilibrium requires that both of these interlaminar stresses must be constant throughout the thickness, which reflects in our laminate homogenization model assumptions (A.2). The local layer stresses in principal material coordinates, due to an applied stress σz=100MPa, are the same in each layer and listed in Table 7. Table 7.
Local layer stresses holding equilibrium to σz = 100 MPa
σ1 σ2 σ3 τ23 τ13 τ12
All −44.5 44.5 100 0 0 0

The stress state is mapped to the stress invariants listed in Table 8. It holds for all layers that fiber failure can occur in the compressive mode, and transverse failure in the tensile mode, if σz>0 and vice versa. Table 8.
Invariant values corresponding to the stress state Table 8
I1 I2 I3 I4
All −44.5 144.5 −4450 0

Applying the interlaminar shear stress τyz=100MPa to the laminate gives the different stresses in each layer listed in Table 9. The corresponding stress invariant values are listed in Table 10. The layers, where failure must occur first, are indicated by the numbers on the failure envelope shown with the left plot in Figure 19. Figure 18.
Predicted stress–strain curves for a ± 35° angle ply laminate made of E-glass/epoxy material (Test case 9). Table 9.
Local layer stresses holding equilibrium to τyz = 100 MPa
σ1 σ2 σ3 τ23 τ13 τ12
0° 0 0 0 100.0 0 0
90° 0 0 0 0 100.0 0
45° 0 0 0 70.7 70.7 0
−45° 0 0 0 70.7 −70.7 0
Table 10.
Invariant values corresponding to the stress state Table 9
I1 I2 I3 I4
0° 0 0 10,000 0
90° 0 0 0 10,000
45° 0 0 5000 5000
−45° 0 0 5000 5000

It appears that failure in the tensile fiber mode is found to appear only in the 90° layer and all transverse failure in the 0° layer. Note that the stressing is primarily interlaminar; the stress components σ1 and σ2, listed in Table 7, appear only because the free transverse strains in all layers are constrained. Initial failure occurring under positive values of σz will immediately disintegrate the laminate and thus coincide with final failure. In the negative regime of σz the laminate might be able to take further load increase after first failure but it is safe to conclude that the same laminate will have lost its ability to withstand tensile loads. The lines plotted in Figure 19 do therefore present both initial and final failure envelopes.

sec.title: Test case 11
sec.p: This case considers the cross-ply laminate [0,90]s made from IM7/8551-7 to predict the τyz versus σz (at σy=σx=0) failure envelope. Note that material and loading are the same as in test case 10.

The layer stresses are the same as those obtained in test case 10 in the 0° and 90° layers. Since failure in the quasi-isotropic laminate is predicted to occur in these layers only, it must be that the failure envelopes plotted in Figure 20 are virtually identical with those in Figure 19. Figure 19.
Predicted failure envelope (τyz versus σz [with σy = σx = 0]) for a quasi-isotropic laminate made of IM7/8551-7 carbon/epoxy material (Test case 10).

sec.title: Test case 12
sec.p:
This case considers the same cross-ply laminate [0,90]s made from IM7/8551-7 as considered by test case 11 to predict the σz versus εz, σz versus εx, and σz versus εy (at σy=σx=0) stress–strain curves. The task of this case is interpreted as follows: apply the load σz, simulate measuring all direct strains, and plot the resulting curves in a diagram the outline of which is given in Reference [11]. The cross-ply-laminate design has the same elastic coupling coefficients in the x and the y directions and therefore the in-plane strains must remain equal, or ɛy=ɛx. Figure 21 shows the results for an assumed linear material, the elasticity constants of which remain at the initial values, and for the provided nonlinear material data. The nonlinear εz versus σz stress–strain curve shows a knee around σz=-185MPa. There is no failure predicted at this level of applied stress but rather the problem is once more reflected that the uniaxial stress–strain curves are provided only up to this stress value and that we have chosen to maintain the secant modulus at σ2=-185MPa if the local stress should exceed that value. Figure 20.
Predicted failure envelope (τyz versus σz [with σy = σx = 0]) for a cross-ply laminate made of IM7/8551-7 carbon/epoxy material (Test case 11). Figure 21.
Predicted stress–strain curves a cross-ply laminate made of IM7/8551-7 carbon/epoxy material under through-thickness compressive loading (Test case 12).

sec.title: A problem with isotropic pressure strength and nonlinear material data
sec.p: Hashin derives the failure criterion for compressive matrix mode by using the argument that if the material is failed in transversely isotropic pressure σ22=σ33=-σ, where all other stress components have zero values, this pressure will be much larger than the uniaxial failure stress. As a consequence, the failure function f4 provides a failure envelope which is not closed for such isotropic pressure as Hashin illustrates with Figure 4 in Reference [12]. This circumstance reflects in the predicted envelopes for test cases 5, 8, 9, and 12, where the strength limits in the regime σ2<0 and σ3<0 are often found by the predicted compressive fiber failure loads (see Figures 12, 15, 19, and 22).

The other problem is that the uniaxial failure loads are much lower than those under isotropic pressure wherefore the measurements do often not completely cover the envelopes or curves required in the test cases. It has here been assumed, without physical basis, that at high strains exceeding the range of the measurements, the materials retain the secant moduli measured at the end of the provided range (see Figure 21), which may be a source of prediction inaccuracy.
It appears that the validity of the stress–strain curve predicted for test case 12 and plotted in Figure 21 suffers from both of the above-mentioned problems.

sec.title: Why damage progression analysis has not been performed
sec.p: Damage progression analysis is of interest where transverse failure events precede further load increase until final failure occurs. Such processes can occur in multidirectional laminates such as considered by the test cases 8 through 12 and here we summarize the observations described along with the test case results and leading to the conclusion that this study does not include a damage progression analysis.

It has been assumed in Test case 8 ([±35]) that the initial damage in transverse tensile modes produces cracks in the two layers that cross each other so that the in-plane load transfer requires interlaminar shear stresses. Since very little is known about the actual test specimens with which the physical testing will be conducted, numerical simulations are not attempted.

Test case 9 investigates loading in the compressive regime only. After applying the isotropic pressure to the [±35] laminate, the stress σy is further increased. A necessary basis for predicting damage progression after initial failure under compressive transverse stresses is the orientation of failure planes which is not in the power of Hashin's criteria.

Test cases 10 and 11 consider a quasi-isotropic [0,90,±45]s and a cross-ply [0,90]s laminate, respectively, and for both laminates the envelopes τyz versus σz are to be predicted. First-ply failure in the tensile regime of σz must be delamination which destroys the laminates integrity by dividing it into two sub laminates. The combination of shear with compressive normal stress may produce transverse failure in planes whose direction cannot be predicted with Hashin's criteria.

Test case 12 applies only the interlaminar pressure to the cross-ply laminate. Although the averaged laminate strains εx and εy are positive, the local transverse stresses σ2 in each layer are negative. After compressive transverse failure at the high loads shown in Figure 21 the matrix will have lost its integrity. It seems very difficult to predict what will happen if, after the matrix material is crushed, the load is further increased.

Obviously, interlaminar failure may often completely remove a laminate's ability to transfer interlaminar stresses. This is in contrast to intralaminar cracking, caused by intralaminar loads, where the applied load can often be increased beyond the first-ply failure loads.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Hashin’s failure criteria for unidirectional composites have been applied to the 12 test cases posed by WWFE-II. By supposing that the interlaminar stresses and the intralaminar strains remain constant throughout the specified laminates, all analysis rests on the here-explained laminate homogenization model which is based on the mentioned continuity assumptions and no physical testing with particular test specimens has been simulated.

The data points for the measured non-linear stress–strain curves have been approximated by polynomials to facilitate the nonlinear calculations. Problems encountered with the nonlinear calculations are reported and the discussion also explains why no damage progression analysis has been performed.

Naturally the triaxial stresses, applied to laminates made from unidirectional fiber composites, involve interlaminar stresses. Under positive interlaminar stress, the failure mode will then be delamination; and initial and final failure will then be the same.

Hashin's criteria are simple to use and can distinguish between failure modes. Predicting failure load under compressive normal stressing requires the calculation of failure-plane orientation which has been outlined by Hashin himself, but not realized in his criteria. It must be expected that this lack may introduce inaccuracy in the predictions of those branches of the failure envelopes governed by compressive transverse failure.
Hashin's theory is not intended to be applied for polymers and metals.
Finally, it is worth pointing out that a comparison is made in Reference [26] between the predictions presented in this paper and those generated by the originators of 11 other failure theories.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The subject of interest is thematically connected with the work on calculation of interlaminar normal stress with finite shell elements which has been supported by the Swiss National Science Foundation under project nos. SNF 200021-105142/1 and SNF 200020-113241/1 and carried out by my colleague R. Roos.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.

sec.p: This section recalls the previously published13,14 laminate homogenization model. The laminate must be loaded so that the interlaminar stresses are constant along the thickness direction and the bending part in the deformation pattern remains negligible; the displacements remain continuous at the layer interfaces. In contrast to the classical theory of laminates plates, the lines perpendicular to the mid-plane of the sub laminate are not required to remain so under load. These assumptions give constant through-the-thickness distributions of the intralaminar strains, (A.1)ɛx=ɛx 0=constɛy=ɛy 0=constγxy=γxy 0=const and the interlaminar stresses: (A.2)σz=σz 0=constτzy=τzy 0=constτzx=τzx 0=const
In the sequel, the superscript 0 marks the respective magnitudes as constant and the upper k accompanies those that can vary from layer to layer.

sec.title: A.1. Development of averaged Hooke’s law for a laminate
sec.p: The material's law for an orthotropic material is written in matrix notation as (A.3)Cε=σ

Here, it is understood that the stiffness matrix C relates the strains and stresses along the xyz reference axes and that the transformation from the material principal axes to the model reference system, which is a rotation about the z axis, has been performed. Both, the strain and the stress vectors contain continuous and non-continuous entries: (A.4)εT={ɛx 0 ɛy 0 ɛz k γzy k γzx k γxy 0}σT={σx k σy k σz 0 τzy 0 τzx 0 τxy k}
The rearranged system of equations reads (A.7)Rkl0=rk

And the entries of matrix R are defined as (A.8)Rij k=C¯ij-C¯i3C¯3j/C¯33Ri3 k=C¯i3/C¯33R3i k=-Ri3 kR33 k=1/C¯33R44 k=C¯55/(C¯44C¯55-C¯45C¯45)R45 k=-C¯45/(C¯44C¯55-C¯45C¯45)R55 k=C¯44/(C¯44C¯55-C¯45C¯45) where the indices i and j take the integer values 1; 2; 6. Simple integration of (A.7) through the thickness t gives the laminate behavior: (A.9)1t∫-t/2 t/2Rkdzl0=1t∫-t/2 t/2rkdz

Since all magnitudes are constant within any single layer, the integration gives a summation rule, (A.10)1t∑k=1 NhkRkl0=1t∑k=1 Nhkrk where hk is the thickness of the kth layer. Abbreviating, (A.11) is written as (A.11)Pl0=p where (A.12)P=1t∑k=1 NhkRk, p=1t∑k=1 Nhkrk and p contains the averages of those values which may vary layer-wise: (A.13)pT={σ¯x σ¯y ɛ¯z γ¯zy γ¯zx τ¯xy}

Finally, equations (A.11) can be rearranged back, to the familiar form of a stiffness matrix, by using the same formalism as when transforming (A.3) into (A.7), (A.14)Cij lam=(Pij-Pi3P3j/P33)/tCi3 lam=Pi3/P33C3i lam=-Ci3 lamC33 lam=t/P33C44 lam=tP55/(P44P55-P45P45)C45 lam=-tP45/(P44P55-P45P45)C55 lam=tP44/(P44P55-P45P45) where the indices i and j take again the integer values 1; 2; 6. The result is the desired three-dimensional stiffness matrix for a general orthotropic laminate.

Some of the test cases for multidirectional laminates specify that averaged laminate stresses be applied. Then, having the compliance matrix (A.15)Slam=(Clam)-1 makes it convenient to calculate the laminate strains simply by the matrix multiplication (A.16)σlam=Slamεlam where the superscript indicates that the intralaminar stresses and the interlaminar strains are averages of the values found in the individual layers.

The macroscopic elastic behavior of the substitute material can be described also in terms of the engineering constants if the laminate is symmetric and balanced. Since Young's moduli describe the ratio between applied uniaxial stress and resulting strain in the same direction, it is obvious that (A.17)Ex=(S11 lam)-1Ey=(S22 lam)-1Ez=(S33 lam)-1υyz=-(S23 lam)Eyυxz=-(S13 lam)Exυxy=-(S12 lam)ExGyz=(S44 lam)-1Gxz=(S55 lam)-1Gxy=(S66 lam)-1
